The claim originated from a 2014 report: run press agency Xinhua, which detailed how a planned live broadcast of the birth of panda cubs was canceled when it was discovered that the panda was not actually pregnant.
The report quoted a panda expert who sug: 3. The Chengdu Giant Panda Breeding Research Center confirmed that the panda Ai Hin, who was scheduled to star in the live broadcast, had a "phantom pregnancy" and was not actually pregnant.
Another panda expert debunked the claim: stating that the behavior was due to hormonal changes rather than purposeful trickery and had been observed in both captive and wild pandas.
